items.message: High river levels today may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible on 27 January 2026. This information is correct as of 07:30 on Tuesday 27 January 2026. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 16cm of water on the road. The causeway at Welney has approximately 12cm of water on the road. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. The Environment Agency are liaising with Norfolk Highways who will decide whether to close the road. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. There are currently no issues on Earith causeway. We are not expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 16:00 on Tuesday 27 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

High river levels on Tuesday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 27 January 2026 . 25mm of rain has been recorded on Tuesday. 
From 13:00 27/01/2026 flooding could begin to approach riverside properties on Forewood Lane and near Crowhurst Recreation Ground. From 16:00 on 27/01/2026, Bexhill Road Recreation Ground, and gardens that back onto the rec (or near the Combe Haven) could be affected. Rain is forecast to stop by 13:00 27/01/2026, with only isolated showers Tuesday afternoon and Wednesday. River levels and flood risk should begin to reduce by 18:00 on 27/01/2026, in Crowhurst, but not until 08:00 on 28/01/2026 in Bulverhythe. River levels might not return near to normal in Bulverhythe until the weekend. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have Install flood protection products in Crowhurst. 
This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 28 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message: The river level at Huish Episcopi is currently 8.91m. The drain level at Huish Episcopi is 8.25m and rising. Flooding will affect the Langport to Muchelney road if this drain level exceeds 7.3m, the Muchelney to Long Load road above 7.86m, the Muchelney to Thorney road above 7.93m and the Muchelney to Draycott road above 8.8m. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m. Pumping will start at Huish Episcopi and Westover stations once river levels allow. The Parrett Relief Channel will be opened once river spillways stop running. After significant rain overnight, we are expecting less rain for the remainder of Tuesday and into Wednesday however blustery showers are forecast which may be heavy at times. We are monitoring the situation closely. Staff are checking the condition of flood banks and spillways. Avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. items.message: River levels across West Somerset remain high on Tuesday 27th January, particularly on the Washford River. Flooding is possible as a result. Areas most at risk include the Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River and the Hawkcombe, Monksilver and Doniford Streams and their tributaries, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected. After significant rain overnight, we are expecting less rain for the remainder of Tuesday and into Wednesday however blustery showers are forecast which may be heavy at times. We are closely monitoring the situation and Field Teams are out clearing debris screens and checking rivers for blockages. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Remain aware of local water levels and weather conditions and don’t put yourself or others at risk. This message will be updated by 1PM on 28/01/2026, or as the situation changes.

The River Tone level at Currymoor Pumping Station is 7.80m. Water will enter Currymoor via Hookbridge spillway if this level exceeds 7.45m. The Drain level at Currymoor Pumping Station is currently 7.81m. Cutts Road and New Road are both closed. Water is flowing out of Currymoor over Athelney Spillway and the A361 is also closed. There is a risk of water overtopping Haymoor flood storage area and affecting Curload and Stan Moor if the Drain level reaches 8.30m. For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels. We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor, and temporary pumps are also being deployed to Northmoor. After significant rain overnight, we are expecting less rain for the remainder of Tuesday and into Wednesday however blustery showers are forecast which may be heavy at times. We are monitoring the situation closely and staff are checking flood banks, spillways and weed screens. Please avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 1PM on 28/01/2026 or as the situation changes.

In Eastleigh, the river may flood Fleming Park, gardens and impact property at Kingfisher Road, Pennine Way, Skipton Road, Magpie Lane, Brookside Way, Stoneham Lane and Stoneham Way. Rain has started to clear the area. Showers are forecast this evening (27/01/2026). The river level has now peaked and will decrease slowly over the next 24 hours. Flooding impacts are expected to continue throughout much of today (27/01/2026). 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and will ensure the river is kept free of reported blockages. 
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions and report blockages to our hotline 0800 80 70 60. 
This message will be updated by 12:00PM on 28 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

High river levels on Tuesday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 27 January 2026 , as a lot of rain (37mm) fell overnight. 
Flooding is affecting land and roads, including Burley Road, Brockenhurst. The river will be bank full as it flows through Martin’s Road and Balmer Lawn Road and may cause garden flooding at Balmer Lawn Road. In Lymington itself, the river will rise over the next 10 hours, but we do not expect impacts to property. During high water, the incoming tide will prevent the river from flowing out to sea. High tide is at 17:18 and at 18:48, 27/01/2026. Showers are forecast over the next 2 days. River levels and flood risk will remain high throughout today. 
We are closing flood gates and will be on site to operate Lymington Toll Bridge flood gate if required 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have and avoid driving through watersplash areas in Brockenhurst.

River levels are rising due to the recent rainfall. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Ebble, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around Ebbesbourne Wake, Bower Chalke, Broad Chalke, Bishopstone, Stratford Tony and Coombe Bissett. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . 
This message will be updated by 5:00PM on 27 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

The River Tone level at Currymoor Pumping Station is 7.73m. Water will enter Currymoor via Hookbridge spillway if this level exceeds 7.45m. The Drain level at Currymoor Pumping Station is currently 7.76m. Cutts Road and New Road are both closed. Water is flowing out of Currymoor over Athelney Spillway and the A361 is also closed. There is a risk of water overtopping Haymoor flood storage area and affecting Curload and Stan Moor if the Drain level reaches 8.30m. For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels. We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor, and temporary pumps are also being deployed to Northmoor. After significant rain overnight, we are expecting less rain for the remainder of Tuesday and into Wednesday with blustery showers, heavy at times.  We are monitoring the situation closely and staff are checking flood banks, spillways and weed screens. Please avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 6PM on 27/01/2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mansbridge and Woodmill on the River Itchen
items.message:
High river levels are expected to cause flooding on Tuesday. 
Flooding is expected on 27 January 2026 as a lot of rain fell in Storm Chandra (35mm). 
Impacts are expected from 16:30 and during high tide. The next high tide will be at 17:45 at a height of 4.58mCD. Flooding will affect the access road and car parking areas near the White Swan Pub and car garage at Mansbridge. Some water may be forced up through the floor of the Pub. Parts of Riverside Park will also be flooded. As the river continues to respond to this mornings rain, levels could also become very high at Gaters Mill. Showers are forecast to continue until today but the worst of the rain should have cleared. Flood risk should reduce for the following tide at 06:15 28/101/2026. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and liaising with Southampton City Council on operation of Woodmill. 
Activate any flood protection products you may have , including defences around the White Swan pub. 
This message will be updated by 12:00PM on 28 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Upper Og Valley
items.message:
Groundwater levels are currently high at our Draycot borehole in the Upper Og Valley. We expect levels to rise over the coming days and levels remain sensitive to further rainfall. 

The forecast is for heavy rain on Tuesday 27 January clearing into a predominantly dry Wednesday 28 January. Showers are then expected into the end of the week. Depending on the rainfall received, we may see localised impacts groundwater impacts. Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. 

We are closely monitoring rainfall and groundwater levels.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Take particular care when driving through flood water both for your own safety and to prevent flooding to others. 

This message will be updated by 12:00 28 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.message:
High groundwater levels are expected to cause flooding. 
Flooding is expected from 24 January 2026 onwards. 
The groundwater level at the Iwerne Hill Farm borehole is rising in response to recent heavy rainfall and will continue to do so as more rain is forecast. Flooding of roads and some properties, especially basements is expected. Residents should deploy any property resilience measures such as pumps, flood barriers and air brick covers. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Keep up to date with groundwater levels on the 'Check for Flooding' site on gov.uk . 
This message will be updated by 11:41AM on 31 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is currently 7.75m. Water will enter Currymoor via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45m. The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.77m. Cutts Road and New Road are closed. Athelney spillway is running and the A361 is also closed. For road closure information please refer to www.somerset.gov.uk/roads-travel-and-parking/emergency-road-closure-gates/. We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor and are deploying temporary pumps to Northmoor pumping station. The River Tone level is currently too high for pumping at Currymoor. We will commence pumping at Currymoor and operate the Parrett Relief Channel once river levels allow. After significant rain overnight, we are expecting less rain for the remainder of Tuesday and into Wednesday with blustery showers, heavy at times. We are monitoring the situation closely and staff are checking flood banks and spillways. Please do not walk, cycle or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 6PM on 27/01/2026, or as the situation changes.

Tomorrow (27/01/2026), Storm Chandra will pass through the south of England, bringing up to 50mm of rain to Hampshire. A combination of high river flows and groundwater may affect a couple of cellars of properties on West Meon High Street and Lynch Lane. Lighter rain is forecast from Wednesday (28/01/2026) to Friday (30/01/2026). Groundwater levels at the borehole at Pound Lane, Meonstoke will continue rising through this week.

This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 27 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Ashley and Milford on Sea, Danes Stream
items.message:
High river levels are expected to cause flooding on Tuesday. 
Flooding is expected on 27 January 2026 from 08:00, as a lot of rain (33mm) fell overnight. 
Flooding will affect footpaths in Milford on Sea and isolated low lying property next to the river at New Valley Road, Barnes Lane, High Street and Sea Road. Rain is forecast to continue until 09:00. River levels and flood risk will remain throughout today. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels . 
Activate any flood protection products you may have . 
This message will be updated by 5:00PM on 27 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

High river levels are expected to cause flooding on Tuesday. 
Flooding is expected on 27 January 2026 from 10:30, as a lot of rain (34mm) fell overnight. 
Flooding will affect the Millennium Meadows, and commercial and industrial property downstream of the main A334. Fareham Road could flood. The river may also affect access to property in Bridge Street. There will be further showers throughout this morning. River levels will continue to rise this morning, and into the afternoon. Levels should start to fall during the afternoon. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels . 
Activate any flood protection products you may have . 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 27 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Continuing high river levels mean flooding remains possible today and overnight into 28 January.

Heavy rain has fallen throughout Monday and into Tuesday and further showers are possible.

Catchments are saturated and rivers are expected to remain high.

Properties and low lying areas remain at risk, particularly in Cullompton and Alexandria Industrial Estate. Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing in these areas. 

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. 
Never drive through flood water, just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car. This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 28 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Par from Luxulyan to Tywardreath Highway
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Rising river levels are expected to cause flooding today. 
Flooding is expected on 27 January 2026 from around 9am 
Heavy rainfall overnight has caused river levels to rise, with further showers forecast throughout Tuesday.

Properties and low lying areas will start to flood from around 9am on Tuesday. The main areas of concern are properties and low lying areas around Luxulyan Sewage Treatment Works, Rosevale Gardens, Tywardreath Highway, and Grove Park. Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing in these areas. 

River levels are forecast to remain high throughout Tuesday. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . 
This message will be updated by 5:00PM on 27 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: West Dean to Dunbridge on the River Dun
items.message:
High river levels are expected to cause flooding on Tuesday. 
Flooding is expected on 27 January 2026 from 09:30, as a lot of rain (36mm) fell overnight 
Flooding will affect property at West Dean, near the railway line at the bottom of Rectory Hill. Showers are forecast for the remainder of the morning. River levels and flood risk will remain high throughout most of today. The river levels should begin to fall by late afternoon. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and keeping the River Dun free of reported blockages. 
Activate any flood protection products you may have and move cars parked at Rectory Hill. 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 27 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Halterworth to Romsey Town Centre on the Tadburn Lake
items.message:
High river levels are expected to cause flooding on Tuesday. 
Flooding is expected on 27 January 2026 from 10:30, as a lot of rain fell in Storm Chandra (37mm). 
Flooding will affect land, roads, gardens, and approach properties at Jenner Way, Sewards Rise, and at Eight Acres. Showers are forecast to continue today, but the worst of the rain should have cleared. River levels and flood risk should begin to reduce by 14:00 27/01/2026. 
We are checking flood defences to make sure that the defence wall remains undamaged. 
Activate any flood protection products you may have . Ensure pumps used to lower water levels are working. 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 27 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

High river levels on Tuesday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 27 January 2026 from 11:30, as a lot of rain (33mm) fell overnight. 
Flooding could affect Boarhunt Mill, surrounding the Mill building. River levels will continue to rise throughout this morning and early afternoon. River levels and flood risk should begin to reduce during the afternoon. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels . 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have and please keep away from the river until water levels begin to fall. 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 27 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Tone from Bathpool to Ham including Ruishton and Creech St Michael
items.message:
Rising river levels are expected to cause flooding today. 
Flooding is expected on 27 January 2026 . 
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Ruishton, Ham Road in Creech St Michael and White Street in Ham , with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around Ruishton, Ham Road in Creech St Michael and White Street in Ham. After significant rain overnight, we are expecting less rain for the remainder of Tuesday and into Wednesday with blustery showers, heavy at times. 
We are closely monitoring the situation and clearing debris screens and checking rivers for blockages. 
Start acting on your flood plan if you have one and activate any flood protection products you may have. 
This message will be updated by 7:00PM on 27 January 2026 or as the situation changes.
